comments.body:
Looking at the source, looks like it's `SupportsColor | false`.
(Although the last line `module.exports = process && support(supportLevel);` implies that it will be undefined if `process` is, but `process` is used earlier anyway, so loading the module would fail if `process` were undefined...)

Yes that's what I had the first time but then the [readme example](https://github.com/chalk/supports-color/blob/master/readme.md) fails to compile.
I thought this was the right compromise because when it returns false, supportsColor.has256 is undefined.

When i change

``` ts
declare const supportsColor: boolean & SupportsColor;
```

to

``` ts
declare const supportsColor: false | SupportsColor;
```

i expect

``` ts
if (supportsColor && supportsColor.hasBasic) {
    // Terminal supports color
}
```

to compile but it fails with

```
Property 'hasBasic' does not exist on type 'false | SupportsColor'.
Property 'hasBasic' does not exist on type 'false'.
```

Is this an issue with Typescript?
